NeuronArray.networkNotes: Purpose:This network demonstrates pattern-recognition and learning utilizing Hebbian Synapses. At the left, the ColorComponent module generates a test pattern representing a color. The three Red, Grn, & Blu neurons fire at rates corresponding to the intensity of the color signal.It is not practical to recognize patterns of rate-encoded signals directly so these three component colors are each fed to RateDecoder3 modules. These evaluate the single entering at “In” and measure the time between each pair of adjacent spikes using leakage coupled with various fixed-weight synapses. The first two columns in each module alternate measuring the timing on every other spike pair. The output me measured in the firing of neurons in the column below “In1,” the faster the spiking the more neurons will fire. The remaining three columns in the module represent a short-term memory which produces spikes dependent on the content of the memory with neurons in the “O0” column spiking to represent a 1 and the “O-0” column representing a zero. This memory mechanism is expanded in “#2 demonstration of tri-state short term memory.”All the outputs of the short-term memory are fully connected to the inputs of the PatternRecognizer module. The second column is there to extend the recognition spikes so they can be viewed at higher network speeds. This module bypasses the Neuron Engine’s handling of Hebbian Synapses and manipulates incoming synapses directly.The “RdOut” neuron fires periodically to request output from the RateDecoder modules. If the “Learning” neuron is not firing, no learning takes place and the network can be used to recognize colors which have been previously stored. If the “Learning” neuron is firing, if a pattern is received which is not previously learned, a neuron is selected to store that pattern and it is fired. The Hebbian synapses are adjusted to begin the learning process. Multiple presentations of the input pattern will strengthen the learning. The neuron selected to store the new pattern is the one which fired least recently.Things to try:With learning disabled, try out various colors by right-clicking the top neuron in the ColorComponent module and selecting it under “Content.” The library network contains only Blue and Black. The dark-blue color 0000c0 is also recognized as blue.With learning enabled, select a different color and notice how the PatternRecognizer allocates a neuron to represent the input pattern and then learns it over a period of subsequent presentations. In the Tri-state short-term memory: Fire the “Read” neuron and notice that neither “O” or “O-“ fires because the memory contains no data. Fire “1” followed by “Read” and notice the output “O” fires indicating a 1 stored in the memory. Fire “0” followed by “Read” and notice that “O-“ fires indicating a 0 stored in memory. After some delay, the memory fades and firing “Read” will once again produce not data.You can change the network dimensions and increase the resolution of the pattern recognition to more realistic parameters. When you drag to resize the PatternRecognizer module, all previously-learned data is lost. When you drag to resize the RateDecoder3 modules, you will need to make a corresponding change in the number of steps represented in the ColorComponent module by right-clicking in the module area and changing the steps value to be one less than the number of detected levels in the RateDecoder3 module. .Current state of development:While this network largely works as advertised, it is the first cut on the two important algorithms in the PatternRecognizer module. The first of these is the synapses modification algorithm. The module calculates the target synapse weights for positive and negative synapses. Then, when one of the neurons in the “P0” column fires, it considers whether the related input has fired within the previous 4 engine cycles and averages the current synapse weight with the target synapse weight. In this manner, all synapse weights are gradually adjusted to learn input patterns. This can be considered a placeholder algorithm which will be improved with future research.The second algorithm is the one which selects which neuron should be used to represent a new pattern. Currently, this simply selects the neuron which has fired the least recently. Like the previous, this is a first-cut. Presuming that there will always be more possible incoming patterns than can be learned, this second algorithm is actually deciding what information to forget, a field of research which is in its infancy.

Neuron.Label: #1 Recotnizes colors stored in the PatternRecognizer module
